ud8.8:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
ud8.8:1.3: Now at that time the dear and beloved granddaughter of Visākhā Migāra’s Mother had just passed away.
ud8.8:1.4: Then, in the middle of the day, Visākhā with wet clothes and hair went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
ud8.8:2.1: “So, Visākhā, where are you coming from in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair?”
ud8.8:2.2: “Sir, my beloved granddaughter has just passed away.
ud8.8:2.3: That’s why I came here in the middle of the day with wet clothes and hair.”
ud8.8:2.4: “Visākhā, would you like as many children and grandchildren as there are people in the whole of Sāvatthī?”
ud8.8:3.1: “But Visākhā, how many people pass away each day in Sāvatthī?”
ud8.8:3.2: “Every day, sir, there are ten people passing away in Sāvatthī.
ud8.8:3.11: or at least one person who passes away every day in Sāvatthī.
ud8.8:3.12: Sāvatthī is never without someone passing away.”
ud8.8:4.1: “What do you think, Visākhā? Would there ever be a time when your clothes and hair were not wet?”
ud8.8:4.3: Enough, sir, with so many children and grandchildren.”
ud8.8:5.1: “Those who have a hundred loved ones, Visākhā, have a hundred sufferings.
ud8.8:5.2: Those who have ninety loved ones,
ud8.8:5.19: or one loved one have one suffering.
ud8.8:5.20: Those who have no loved ones have no suffering. They are free of sorrow, stains, and anguish I say.”
ud8.8:6.1: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud8.8:7.2: and the countless forms of suffering in the world
ud8.8:7.3: occur because of those that we love;
ud8.8:7.4: without loved ones they do not occur.
ud8.8:8.1: That’s why those who have no loved ones <j>at all in the world
ud8.8:8.2: are happy and free of grief.
ud8.8:8.3: So aspiring to the sorrowless and stainless,
ud8.8:8.4: have no loved ones in the world at all.”
